text_description: Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat is premiered at the Teatro Libertad. The sarsuwela features dances such as balitaw and balse which are dances derived from Hispanic forms.
Foreign vaudeville groups continue to perform locally such as the Japanese Infantile company with its “Japanese ballet” and the Baroufski Imperial Russian Circus in 1902.
Western dances are performed at the grand balls of the 1908 carnival and subsequent carnivals.
Ballroom dancing such as waltz, fox-trot, quickstep, and swing are performed at the Santa Ana Cabaret (in photo) and other similar establishments. (Photo from Eduardo de Leon Collection)

media_caption: Cover of "Jazzy Jazzy Sound in All Chinatown," by Louis Borromeo (featured in cover wearing a costume)
media_credit: Photo from Fred Fischer, Inc., Wikimedia Commons
text_description: Cebuano jazz artist Luis Borromeo aka Borromeo Lou (pictured in the cover of his composition) is back from America and opens the first bodabil company featuring jazz music and various acts with pop and theatrical dances from the United States at the Olympic Stadium in Manila. (Photo from Fred Fischer, Inc., Wikimedia Commons)

media_credit: Photo from Bain News Service Collection, Library of Congress
text_description: Anna Pavlova, lead dancer of the Imperial Russian Ballet, graces the Manila Grand Opera House, enticing local girls to study ballet, among them Anita Kane. (Photo from Bain News Service Collection, Library of Congress)

The Kahirup organization composed of sugar barons holds lavish annual balls at the Manila Hotel, highlighted by a rigodon de honor with the participation of high society women dressed in elegant ternos. Photo: Kahirup Ball at the Manila Hotel in 1934. (Isidra Reyes and Lou Gopal)

media_caption: Francisca Reyes, center, seated, with the University of the Philippines (UP) Folk Song and Dance Troupe, 1930
article_title: Dance 1937 UP Folk Song and Dance Troupe
text_description: To revive and popularize Filipino songs and dances, Francisca Reyes-Tolentino establishes the UP Folk Song and Dance Troupe. (Photo from Rosalia Merino-Santos)
Manila Ballet Moderne premieres Pictures at an Exhibition at the Manila Metropolitan Theater with choreography and costumes by Trudl Dubsky-Zipper.
In television, Vilma Santos continues her variety show that showcases spectacular dance numbers in Vilma in Person (1986-95) over GMA 7.

article_title: Dance 1989 National Dance Festival and Conference in Iloilo
text_description: The first CCP National Dance Festival and Conference is launched in Iloilo with activities happening in other Visayan cities.
The CCP through its Outreach program, conducts folkdance workshops on the regional level with members of PFDS, particularly its board members acting as resource persons.

article_title: Dance 1990 Gawad CCP Paz CIelo Belmonte
text_description: Paz Cielo Belmonte receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
World Dance Alliance is established on the occasion of the Hong Kong International Dance Conference in 1990 by Carl Wolz.

CCP launches the folk dance festival Sari-Saring Sayaw, Sama-Samang Galaw: Mga Tradisyon at Interpretasyon, held during the Philippine Arts Month in February. The festival brings together folk dance groups from all over the country.

media_caption: Maniya Barredo as Odette in Swan Lake, 1970s
text_description: Maniya Barredo receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. (Photo from Steve Villaruz)

The First Asian Dance Music Convention is held at the Philippine Convention Center with the participations of b-boys, hip-hop crews, and enthusiasts from all over the Philippines and around the globe.
The Association of Ballet Academies, Philippines (ABAP) is established to improve classical ballet education in the Philippines.
Rosalia Merino-Santos receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. (Photo from Steve Villaruz)
CCP launches the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art with one volume dedicated to dance.

media_caption: Duwa’a jin ritual held during the rice harvest season among the Sama Dilaut in Sitangkai, Tawi-Tawi, 2007
text_description: During full moon, the Sama Dilaut perform rituals with dancing called magjinn aka igal jinn to appease malevolent or angered spirits. Shown here is the duwa’a jin ritual held during the rice harvest season among the Sama Dilaut in Sitangkai, Tawi-Tawi, 2007. (Photo by Hamka Malabong)

media_caption: A portrait that is traditionally believed to be a representation of Antonio Pigafetta based off a statue in the Civic Museum of Vicenza.
text_description: In Cebu, Antonio Pigafetta, Magellan’s chronicler, describes a dance ritual with swine sacrifice. Two old women don special garments and play reed trumpets while dancing around a pig with cloth and palm leaves, until one of them pierces the animal's heart.(Photo from WIkimedia Commons)

media_caption: Natives in the background dancing the kumintang in a print by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay, 1734
text_description: An engraving by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay from Velarde’s map illustrates the kumintang, a music and dance style indigenous to the areas presently known as Batangas. (Photo from CCP)
The short period introduces a dance called ba-Ingles, from the words “baile” and “Ingles” or English dance.

media_caption: Pandanggo sa ilaw, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company
text_description: Jean Mallat (1846) writes about how deftly the Indios learn Spanish dances, such as the fandango, the zapateado, and the cachucha. Photo shows Bayanihan Dance Company performing Pandanggo sa Ilaw. (Photo from Mario Feir Filipiniana Library)

media_caption: Kundiman, a popular song and dance genre from 1800s to 1860s
media_credit: Photo from Biblioteca Nacional de España Collection
text_description: Jose Honorato Lozano documents in water color the folk song-dance kundiman, popular from the beginning of the 1800s.

media_caption: Original image/icon of Our Lady of Turumba, enshrined in the church of San Pedro Alcantara in Pakil, Laguna, 1788
media_credit: Photo by Randy Caponpon DM, Wikimedia Commons
text_description: Paul de la Gironiere’s book describes the turumba in Pakil, Laguna in honor of the Nuestra Señora de los Dolores de Turumba(pictured). People who are sick and with disabilities join the throng of dancing devotees, hoping to be cured. (Photo by Randy Caponpon DM, Wikimedia Commons)
Easier travel route of Spain-Philippines-Spain facilitates the entry of artists and performers from Europe, resulting in the further spread of European social dances in the Philippines.
Another song-dance form from Cuba called bolero spreads to the Hispanic world.

media_caption: Spanish composer and author Francisco Asenjo Barbieri (1823–1894)
media_credit: Photo from 15 June 1894 Issue of Austrian Art Chronicle, AustriaN Newspapers Online
text_description: Dario de Cespedes and his group stage the full-length Spanish zarzuela Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire), the first zarzuela performed in the Philippines, written by Ventura de la Vega, with music by Francisco Asenjo Barbieri (in photo) of the Sociedad Artística del Teatro-Circo. (Photo from 15 June 1894 Issue of Austrian Art Chronicle, AustriaN Newspapers Online)
European performing groups continue to perform zarzuelas, operettas, operas, and can-can in local venues.

Jose Rizal publishes Noli Me Tangere in Berlin, Germany. The novel will later inspire works by future generations of dancers and choreographers: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco's Noli Dance Suite, Cora Iñigo's Sisa (pictured), Agnes Locsin's Elias, and Paul Alexander Morales's Crisostomo Ibarra. (Photo by Mario Pamintuan)

article_title: Dance 1887 El Hijo de Su Papa
text_description: Another zarzuela in 1887, El Hijo de Su Papa, features Patrocinio Tagaroma dancing cancan and tango numbers passionately received by the audience.
Dances are performed at the celebrations in Malolos Congress on Sep 15 and during the ratification on Sep 29 of the independence proclaimed at Kawit, Cavite on Jun 12.
Groups in the international vaudeville circuit perform in the Philippines, like the Lilliputians in 1901 with their “ballet girls.”

media_caption: Stage, orchestra, and balconies of the Teatro Zorrilla, Calle Azcaragga (now Claro M. Recto Avenue), Manila, 1911, where operas, sarsuwela, concerts, and other musical events were held in the first decades of the American period
text_description: Teatro Zorrilla (in photo) presents Novelty in Manila, an American production featuring various acts like comedy skits, acrobatics, contortionists’ display, singing and dancing. (Photo from Filipinas Heritage Library)

media_caption: Dr. Herbert Zipper, conductor of Manila Symphony Orhestra which performs at the Metropolitan Theater
text_description: Trudl Dubsky-Zipper and her husband, orchestra conductor Herbert Zipper (in photo), join the underground resistance. (Photo courtesy of Lou Gopal, www.ManilaNostalgia.com)
Trudl Dubsky-Zipper (in photo) continues to conduct dance classes on the rooftop of her apartment. (Photo from Dubsky Family)

media_credit: Photo from Anita M. Kane: Studio of the Classic Dance, souvenir program, 1950
text_description: Anita Kane (in photo), kept as a virtual prisoner at the internment camp in the University of Santo Tomas in Manila for years, is released with other “internees.”
Bruna P. Seril establishes the Philippine Dance Company of New York, performing folk dances researched by Francisca Reyes-Aquino.

media_caption: Rex Theater, an artdeco structure built during the 1930's located in Ongpin Street, Binondo Manila
article_title: Dance 1946 Dubsky-Zipper and Manila Ballet Moderne
text_description: Trudl Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne presents dance concerts for the troops of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) at the undamaged Rex Theater (in photo). (Photo from Eduardo de Leon Collection)

Francisca Reyes-Aquino establishes the Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS) along with former members of the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club and the Bureau of Education Folk Dance Club, with the objective of preserving and promoting the traditional characteristics of Philippine folk dances.

At the Manila Grand Opera House, the first jazz dance group, Shirley & the Moderners, is formed by Al Quinn (1933- ) with Jamin Alcoriza, Jack Jacinto, Arturo Zamora, Rally Calvo, Chito Feliciano, Shirley Santos, and Marie Cui.

Julie Borromeo (in photo) arrives from the United States after training with Luigi and Matt Matox, opens the first school to formally teach jazz dance, along with her sister, Rose Borromeo. Julie also established the Julie Borromeo Dance Company, the first formal jazz company in the Philippines. (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

Activists affiliated with the Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyonaryong Sining present Pest of Badway in front of CCP. Directed by Behn Cervantes and Leo Rimando, it parodies Best of Broadway, which is showing at the CCP.

media_caption: Imelda Marcos bestowing the National Artist Award on Francisca Reyes-Aquino, assisted by Reyes-Aquino’s daughter, Celia, 1973
text_description: Francisca Reyes-Aquino is proclaimed first National Artist for Dance. (Photo from Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation)
Juan C. Miel publishes Samar Folk Dances.
Teresita Pascua-Ines publishes Ilocano Folk Dances.
The Philippine High School for the Arts, atop Mt Makiling in Laguna, opens offering scholarships in dance and the other arts.

Alay sa Pangulo, a show to celebrate the birthday of Ferdinand Marcos at the CCP, has Van Cliburn, Margot Fonteyn, and Rudolf Nureyev as guest performers. Marcos confers the International Artist Award on Fonteyn and Cliburn.

Art Association of Bacolod initiates the MassKara Festival, a street dance of smiling masks and colorful costumes, to cheer up the people of Negros Occidental who are suffering due to the fall of the sugar industry and the death of their relatives in the sunken MV Don Juan. This is the start of the annual festival. (Photo by Cesar Parroco)

article_title: Dance 1980 Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan
text_description: Jovita Sison-Friese releases Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan.
The first Makiisa Festival features anti-Marcos performances, exhibits, lectures, and workshops. It will be followed by a second one the next year.
Ballet Philippines represents the country in the 4th ASEAN Festival of Performing Arts hosted by the CCP.
The first Cordillera Day celebration is held in Sadanga, Mt Province with indigenous dances and music performed by the participating groups.
Balletfest is launched with the participation of more than 20 dance companies and schools from all over the country.
To showcase folk dance groups from the whole archipelago, CCP launches the annual folk dance festival Pang-alay: A Festival of Philippine Folk Dances. (Photo by Julio Sambajon)

In dance sport or competitive ballroom, the DanceSport Council of the Philippines, Inc holds its first dance congress at the Ninoy Aquino Stadium to introduce the competitive style of ballroom dancing. Two couples represent the Philippines in the international competition in Bangkok.
Corazon Generoso-Iñigo receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. (Photo from Steve Villaruz)
The CCP and the NCCA, in cooperation with World Dance Alliance-Philippines, holds the Philippine International Dance Conference in Manila.

The Philippine Folk Dance Society launches the first book in the 8-volume series titled Sayaw: Dances of the Philippine Islands. Succeeding volumes will come out in 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2005, 2010, 2014. Editors are Larry Gabao and Franco Velas.

Dayaw 2000, a traditional arts festival with indigenous dances from all over the Philippines, is held at the Rizal Park, organized by the CCP and NCCA. It is held in different provinces in the following years up to the 2010s.
Eddie Elejar receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. (Photo from CCP)
Basilio Esteban Villaruz's Treading Through 45 Years of Philippine Dance is published.
The first contemporary dance festival in the Philippines, the Wi Fi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival, begins in CCP.

media_caption: Karga Tapas, Dance Pull Company, CCP, Manila, 2008
text_description: Dance Pull Company's Karga Tapas, choreographed by Dwight Rodrigazo about the labors of the sacadas in Negros sugar plantations, is critically-acclaimed at the Wi Fi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival. (Photo from CCP)
Felicitas L. Radaic receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

media_caption: Women and children doing the One Billion Rising flash mob dance, Davao City, 2014
text_description: The dance flash mob is utilized by the campaign One Billion Rising led by the women’s group Gabriela, OBR coordinator Monique Wilson, and feminist nun Sr Mary John Mananzan. The successful campaign is repeated in succeeding years all over the country. (Photo from Kilab Multimedia)
Agnes Locsin receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. (Photo by Jojo Mamangun)

The CCP launches the 1st CCP National Ballet Competition in Nov 2014 open to ballet dancers, choreographers, ballet masters, ballet school participants and their supporters from different parts of the country.

media_caption: 2015 Ramon Magsaysay Awardee Ligaya Fernando-Amilbangsa receiving the Award from Philippine President Benigno Aquino III
text_description: Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award. (Photo from Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)
Basilio Esteban Villaruz receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. (Photo from Steve Villaruz)

media_caption: The pagdiwata ritual of the Tagbanwa, Palawan, ca 1983
text_description: The Palawan and Tagbanwa of Palawan Island perform primordial dances such as the pagdiwata ritual, performed here ca 1983. (Filipinas Heritage Library)
